childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1992-2004

You were born the year Los Angeles burned. The Rodney King verdict came down on April 29th, and within hours the city was on fire—fifty-five people dead, a billion dollars in damage, the National Guard deployed, anger that had been building for decades finally exploding on live television. You were probably a few weeks or months old, sleeping through the chaos. Welcome to America.

That same spring, Bill Clinton won the presidency by playing saxophone on Arsenio Hall and promising a bridge to the twenty-first century. The Cold War had just ended. America was the unchallenged superpower. Everyone thought things were getting better. They were, briefly.

The Real World premiered on MTV the year you were born—seven strangers picked to live in a house and have their lives taped. It invented reality television and the surveillance culture that would define your entire adult life. The concept seemed novel then: watch real people being real. Now it's just called social media.

Your childhood was the last gasp of analog existence. You had a landline with caller ID, which felt like magic—you could see who was calling before picking up! You rented movies from Blockbuster and argued with your siblings about late fees. If you wanted to know something, you looked it up in an encyclopedia or asked a librarian. Google launched when you were six, but it would be years before 'googling' became a verb.

You were six when Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel and adults around you wept for someone they'd never met. Ten during Columbine, which turned schools into places with lockdown drills and metal detectors, places where you practiced surviving. Nine on September 11, 2001—third grade, watching towers fall on classroom televisions, teachers crying, parents picking you up early, the world splitting into before and after.

Technology arrived in waves. Your family's first computer probably ran Windows 95 or 98. You played Oregon Trail until everyone died of dysentery. You got your first email address—something embarrassing with numbers and underscores—sometime in elementary school. AIM dominated your middle school years with its away messages and buddy lists. MySpace owned high school. By the time Facebook arrived, you were already a veteran of oversharing online.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research, which finally settled the boundary debate after years of arguing. Your generation is about 72 million Americans, which made you the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. You grew up being told you were special, that you could be anything, that the world was waiting for you. Then you graduated into a crater.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. You were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. Old enough to watch the towers fall, young enough to have your entire worldview shaped by the aftermath rather than disrupted by it. Security checkpoints, forever wars, color-coded terror alerts—that became your normal. The pre-9/11 world is a foreign country you barely remember, glimpsed in old movies where people walk friends to airport gates.

You graduated into either the Great Recession itself or its long toxic aftermath. If you went straight to work, you hit the worst job market since the Depression. If you went to college, you graduated into a crater. Entry-level jobs required three years of experience. Unpaid internships were sold as 'opportunities.' The gig economy wasn't freedom—it was desperation rebranded with app notifications and contractor status.

Your generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. Your generation gets blamed for killing industries, demanding participation trophies, and being simultaneously too optimistic and too pessimistic. In reality, you just graduated into the worst economy since your great-grandparents, watched housing prices triple while wages stagnated, and got told your struggle was a character flaw instead of a policy failure. You didn't kill Applebee's—you couldn't afford it.

Millennials are the bridge generation. You remember life before smartphones but can't imagine life without them now. You're digital natives who know what dial-up sounds like. You're nostalgic for a past you barely experienced and anxious about a future that keeps getting worse. You contain contradictions because your era does.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Unforgiven won Best Picture and Clint Eastwood reminded everyone he could still act while deconstructing the Western mythology that made him famous. Disney released Aladdin with Robin Williams improvising as the Genie. Wayne's World brought SNL sketches to theaters and taught everyone to say 'Schwing!' and 'Party on!' without irony. Sister Act put Whoopi Goldberg in a nun's habit, which somehow worked.

Musically, 1992 was grunge's coronation. Nirvana's Nevermind went platinum, and suddenly flannel and angst were mainstream. Pearl Jam and Soundgarden were everywhere. Dr. Dre dropped The Chronic and changed hip-hop forever with G-funk production and Snoop Dogg's introduction. Whitney Houston's 'I Will Always Love You' dominated radio for what felt like an entire year. Boyz II Men made everyone slow dance at middle school prom to songs about heartbreak they didn't understand yet.

Television in 1992 was transforming. The Real World invented reality TV—seven strangers in a house, cameras everywhere, conflicts manufactured or real depending on your cynicism. MTV still played music videos. Cartoon Network launched, giving you a dedicated channel for animation that would babysit your entire generation. The Tonight Show was still Johnny Carson's, but not for long.

Your childhood was Rugrats, Hey Arnold!, and Pokémon arriving like a cultural invasion you couldn't resist. Your middle school years belonged to TRL, boy bands versus girl groups, Britney versus Christina debates that felt genuinely important. High school brought emo, MySpace profiles with carefully curated auto-playing songs, and the early YouTube era when viral videos were still surprising rather than algorithmic.

The pop culture you absorbed was pre-algorithm. You couldn't skip ads—you endured them. You couldn't binge shows—you waited a week between episodes and discussed theories with friends at school. Music came on physical CDs you bought at Best Buy or downloaded illegally on Napster. Movies you actually went to theaters to see. Culture was something you experienced on its schedule, not yours.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the first smartphone prototype appeared—IBM's Simon, a brick-sized device that nobody bought but that predicted everything that came later. It had a touchscreen, email, apps. It cost $900 and sold 50,000 units. Thirty years later, everyone would carry something a thousand times more powerful and consider it indispensable.

The World Wide Web existed in 1992 but wasn't public yet. Most people had never heard the word 'internet.' Personal computers were expensive beige boxes that ran DOS commands nobody understood. Windows 3.1 launched that year, which made PCs slightly less terrifying for normal people. The first text message was sent in December: 'Merry Christmas.' The idea that everyone would communicate primarily through text was science fiction.

You were three when Windows 95 came out, complete with the Rolling Stones song and lines around the block at computer stores. You were six when Google launched—lowercase, minimalist, promising not to be evil. Twelve when the first iPod arrived, a thousand songs in your pocket. Fourteen when Facebook opened to high schools. Fifteen when the iPhone dropped and everything before it instantly looked prehistoric.

You didn't grow up with smartphones—you watched them colonize everything in real-time, year by year, feature by feature. This makes you part of the last generation to remember life before the internet was mandatory. You know what boredom felt like before screens filled every empty moment. You printed MapQuest directions. You used a card catalog at the library. You can explain dial-up noises to younger people who don't believe you.

Your relationship with technology is complicated in ways that pure digital natives don't experience. You can troubleshoot both your parents' WiFi and your grandparents' VCR. You've watched social media go from fun to mandatory to exhausting to genuinely concerning. You understand that convenience comes at a cost—you just accepted the terms and conditions without reading them, like everyone else.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born during the LA riots—four days of chaos after the Rodney King verdict acquitted officers filmed beating a Black man on the ground. America's racial tensions exploded on live television. Fifty-five people died. A billion dollars in property destroyed. It was the first major civil unrest you existed during, though you'd have to learn what it meant later. Similar footage would return throughout your life, proving that some things didn't change.

You were one when the World Trade Center was bombed the first time—a truck full of explosives in the parking garage, six dead, a thousand injured. It was supposed to collapse the towers. It didn't. Eight years before the second, successful attempt that would define your generation.

You were three when the Oklahoma City bombing happened—168 dead, including 19 children in a daycare. Domestic terrorism before anyone used that phrase commonly. You were six when Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel, and the global mourning taught you that collective grief was a spectacle now, performed on television for billions.

You were seven when Columbine happened. School shootings existed before, but Columbine created the template—the rolling coverage, the blame games, the copycat fear. You probably had your first lockdown drill before fifth grade. Schools became places where you practiced hiding, not just learning.

You were nine during 9/11. You watched the towers fall, possibly in a classroom, possibly at home with parents who didn't know what to say. Teachers crying. Adults looking scared in ways you'd never seen. The world split into before and after that morning. Everything that followed—the wars, the surveillance, the fear—happened during your formative years.

You were fifteen during the 2008 financial crisis. Old enough to understand something terrible was happening, young enough to inherit all the consequences. College costs were skyrocketing. Jobs were disappearing. The economy you graduated into was a wasteland dressed up in recovery statistics.

By your early twenties, Occupy Wall Street articulated what everyone felt but couldn't name. By your mid-twenties, marriage equality was legal and Trump announced his campaign. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world—killing over a million Americans. History kept happening, faster and worse than anyone expected. You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than any generation since the Greatest Generation.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated college around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, into the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. If you went straight to work after high school, you hit the worst job market in eighty years. If you went to college, you graduated into wreckage. The job market was 'recovering,' which meant it existed again, not that it worked. Entry-level positions required years of experience. 'Networking' became a verb you used constantly but hated viscerally.

Your generation normalized the 'side hustle' because one income stream wasn't enough. You drove for Uber, sold things on Etsy, monetized hobbies that previous generations did for fun. The gig economy wasn't liberation—it was survival dressed up in startup language and contractor forms. You were an entrepreneur, which is what they call someone without benefits.

You watched the workplace transform. Open offices replaced cubicles, which had replaced private offices. Standing desks appeared. Then everyone got back problems. Kombucha showed up in break room fridges alongside ping pong tables and 'unlimited PTO' policies that nobody actually used because the culture punished time off.

You're the generation that normalized job-hopping. Not because you're disloyal, but because companies stopped being loyal first. The implicit contract—work hard, get rewarded, stay for decades, retire with a pension—was already dead by the time you arrived. You learned to chase raises by leaving, not staying. Two years became a long tenure. Five became unusual. Ten became suspicious.

COVID reshaped everything when you were in your late twenties. Remote work went from rare perk to standard practice. You proved you could be productive from home, which means employers now expect you to be productive from everywhere, all the time. The boundary between work and life dissolved. Your laptop became a coworker you couldn't escape, pinging at midnight, lurking during dinner.

You've been told to 'follow your passion' while watching passionate people burn out. You've been told to 'hustle' by people who inherited their positions. You've been told the economy is recovering while rent takes more of your paycheck every year. The career advice you received was written for a world that no longer exists.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that grew up with dating apps but still remembers meeting people in person. Tinder launched when you were about twenty-one. By the time you were actively dating as an adult, swiping was standard practice. Romance became a sorting algorithm you couldn't opt out of if you wanted to participate.

You probably met at least one significant partner online, which your parents find mildly concerning and your younger siblings find completely unremarkable. You're the bridge generation—old enough to remember asking someone out face-to-face with your voice shaking, young enough to have normalized doing it through screens where rejection is just silence.

Your communication style evolved with the platforms. You started with AIM away messages that were really just poetry for your crush. You graduated to Facebook wall posts, migrated to texting, and now maintain relationships through a rotating cast of apps. You remember when calling someone was normal. Now it's suspicious. 'Why are you calling me? Is someone dead?'

Your generation delayed marriage, cohabitation, and children longer than any before. Not because you don't want these things, but because weddings cost $30,000, houses cost half a million, and childcare costs more than college tuition. The life script your parents followed isn't available at a price you can afford. You're not commitment-phobic—you're priced out.

You've maintained friendships across geographic distance via group chats, social media, and occasional reunions. You've watched friend groups fragment as people moved for jobs, partners, or cheaper cities. You know how to feel close to people you rarely see in person and distant from people who live next door. Connection became asynchronous, which is both freeing and lonely.

You've normalized therapy and talking about mental health in relationships. Previous generations suffered in silence. You suffer out loud, which is marginally better. You've learned that relationships require 'work,' which nobody told your grandparents, who just stayed married because divorce was expensive and embarrassing.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were eight when the dot-com bubble burst—something that happened to adults, not to you, but you absorbed the anxiety. Sixteen during the 2008 financial crisis, watching parents worry about jobs and retirement accounts. Twenty-eight during COVID's economic collapse. You've watched the economy implode three times before turning thirty-five. Your financial worldview is best described as 'waiting for the next crash while hoping to outrun it.'

Your relationship with money is defined by never having quite enough. Student loans followed you into adulthood. Housing prices climbed faster than your income could possibly match. The gap between where you are and where you were promised you'd be grows wider every year despite doing everything right.

You save compulsively because you've seen stability evaporate overnight. You invest reluctantly, distrustful of markets that seem designed to extract wealth from people like you and transfer it to people unlike you. You play the game because opting out means losing by default. At least playing gives you a chance.

You've been lectured about spending habits by people who bought houses when they cost two years' salary. The median home price in 1992 was around $100,000. Now it's over $400,000 in most markets, much higher in cities with jobs. Wages have roughly doubled. Housing has quadrupled. The math doesn't work, and everyone who did the math when it worked keeps telling you to try harder.

Your generation is redefining success because the old definitions are unattainable. It's not owning property—it's finding an apartment you can afford in a city with jobs. It's not retiring at 65—it's hoping to retire at all. It's not building wealth for your children—it's hoping you won't burden them with your care. The goalposts moved. Nobody told you. You figured it out when you arrived and found an empty field.

You've watched cryptocurrency boom, crash, boom, and crash again. You've watched housing prices defy gravity and logic. You've watched inflation eat your raises. The rules of financial success keep changing, written by people who already won and revised to ensure you can't follow the same path.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's greatest strength is also its trap: you believe in self-improvement as salvation. You track everything—sleep scores, step counts, screen time, meditation streaks. You approach personal growth like an engineering problem, optimizing yourself toward a happiness that keeps receding as you approach. The problem is some things can't be optimized. Systemic failure doesn't respond to better habits.

You're so skilled at adapting to dysfunction that you sometimes forget to challenge it. You've normalized precarious employment, unaffordable housing, healthcare tied to jobs you can lose at any moment. You've learned to survive broken systems instead of demanding they be fixed. Resilience became resignation somewhere along the way.

You're conflict-averse in ways that cost you. You've been trained to be collaborative, agreeable, and professional—which often means accepting less than you deserve because making demands feels uncomfortable. You'll take 'exposure' instead of payment. You'll absorb extra work without extra compensation. You'll stay in bad situations because leaving feels worse than staying until it doesn't.

You're so steeped in irony that earnestness feels risky. You can't just care about something—you have to care about it ironically, or care while acknowledging the absurdity of caring, or care while pre-emptively mocking yourself for caring. This makes advocating for yourself surprisingly difficult. Your defensive armor is also your prison.

Your generation is chronically online in ways that sometimes substitute for offline action. You can organize on social media, but voter turnout in local elections is dismal. You can cancel celebrities, but changing laws requires showing up to boring meetings. The dopamine hit of digital activism feels like progress even when it isn't. Engagement metrics aren't the same as power.

You've been told you're special so many times that ordinary feels like failure. Your parents said you could be anything. Childhood participation trophies told you everyone wins. Reality told you something different, and the gap between expectation and outcome fuels much of your anxiety. Ordinary is fine. Nobody told you that growing up.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2012-2022): You graduated into an economy still recovering from 2008—'recovering' meaning corporations were posting profits again, not that jobs paid living wages. You took positions beneath your qualifications because something was better than nothing. You lived with roommates or parents longer than planned. You watched rent consume more of your income every year while wages barely moved. This was supposed to be your decade of exploration and growth. Instead, it was about survival and adaptation, putting out fires rather than building foundations. You ended it in a pandemic, which felt about right.

Your 30s (2022-2032): You're in this decade now. You're probably earning more than your twenties but still not enough for the life you were promised. You're watching Gen Z enter the workforce with different expectations and older generations finally retire with resources you'll never accumulate. This is supposedly your 'settling down' period, but settling requires stability you don't have. You're building a life on foundations that keep shifting. If you want kids, the biological and financial clocks are both ticking louder.

Your 40s (2032-2042): Statistically, this will be your peak earning decade. You'll have more authority, more clarity, more acceptance of what you can't change. Your parents will be elderly, bringing new responsibilities and costs. You might be managing aging parents, children, and career demands simultaneously—the sandwich generation in full effect. This is when you either double down on what you've built or burn it down and start fresh. Most people do a little of both.

Your 50s (2042-2052): By now, you'll have survived multiple economic crises, at least one pandemic, and countless 'unprecedented' events that happen every few years now. You'll be close to traditional retirement age but unlikely to retire traditionally. You'll mentor younger colleagues who don't understand why you're so cautious, so scarred, so obsessed with emergency funds. You'll be annoyed at their optimism and jealous of it simultaneously.

Your 60s and beyond (2052+): Retirement, if it happens, will look nothing like your parents' version. Part-time work, gig economy participation, or reliance on family are all likely scenarios. Social Security's future is uncertain. Climate change will have reshaped geography and economics in ways nobody can fully predict. The world will be unrecognizable from the one you were born into. You'll tell younger people about landlines, Blockbuster, and life before smartphones. They'll think you're exaggerating. You won't be.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you. You're part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): You're more educated, more diverse, and significantly less wealthy at the same age. Gen X inherited a functioning economy and watched it break. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing. They got affordable college—you got student loans that follow you for decades. They got pensions—you got 401(k)s with fees that eat your gains. They got starter homes—you got starter apartments you can barely afford in cities with jobs.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were your age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. You control 7%. Boomers bought houses for two or three years' salary, often on single incomes. You're spending that on rent. Boomers expected pensions and Social Security. You expect neither to exist in recognizable form by the time you need them.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're similar but slightly more bruised by disappointment. You remember when things felt possible, when optimism seemed reasonable. Gen Z doesn't have that baseline—they arrived after hope left. You believed the system could work if fixed. Gen Z assumes it's broken beyond repair and builds workarounds. You adapted to smartphones arriving in your teens. They don't remember before. You're the last generation with clear memories of the before times.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising rates of deaths from suicide, overdose, and alcohol—the 'deaths of despair' that economists track as a marker of how your generation is doing. Spoiler: not great.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic problems than any generation before. You've normalized mental health treatment. You've pushed for workplace equity. You've demanded that institutions acknowledge problems they used to ignore. You inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. That matters, even if it doesn't pay the rent.

year_events: LA riots erupted after the Rodney King verdict
Mall of America opened as largest US mall
The Real World premiered on MTV
